Robbery (Title a) implies Thelt; the injured person consequently

may proceed by either actio surti othonorum vi raptorum, though the ,

latter, being praetorian, was, so lar as it was penal, barred by prescription in an annus utilis. The distinction between the two offences is that Robbery is always accompanied by violence; there is also adillerence in the nature ol the remedy, by which, should the offense be treated as rapina, both penalty and compensation are simultaneously recovered, whereas the actio furti is penal only, compensation being obtained by condictio furtiva. A stringent enactment ol Valentinian is here noticed‚ which was designed to check violent seizure ol property, moveable or immoveable‚ under the pretence that the seizor believed it to be his own; a plea which excluded the presumption ol dolus malus, and consequently exempted him lrom the penalties ol both Thelt and

Robbery. Itis also observed that to enable one to sue on the latter one’s interest in the property may be even more slender than is required to support an actio surti.

The third Title treats of the lex Aquilia, an early statute which

practically contains the whole os the law ol Injury to property, damnum iniuria datum. The peculiarity ol this Delict is that mere negligence is sufficient to render one liable to its penalties: ‘non minus quam ex dolo ex culpa quisque hac lege tenetur.¹ What amounts to negligence in this connection is clearly shown bya series os illustrations. The lex Aquilia contained three chapters, the second ol which was obsolete under Justinian. Tbe first dealt with the killlng ol slaves and certain domesticated animals, and imposed a penalty of the highest value such slave or animal had borne at any time within the year imme· diately preceding. The third related to almost every other kind ol damage to property: its penalty was such property’s highest value within the last thirty days before the wrong was done. Certain exten· sions ol the statute by the ‘interpretatio’ ol the older jurists‚ and by the action of the praetor, to cases not strictly within its letter are noticed‚ and the wide meaning ol ‘damnum’ to be gathered from its terms is illustrated by examples. .

The fourth Delict (Iniuria, Title 4) is aimed at the honour, good name, and reputation ol a free person: it comprlses such acts as assault and battery, libel, slander, and in lact all treatment ol or de· meanour towards a man by which his character is likely to be injured.
